title: 108_s1709
content: The Act is known as the "Security and Freedom Ensured Act of 2003" or the "SAFE Act." It limits roving wiretaps under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978. Section 105(c) of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 is amended to include requirements for electronic surveillance targets and locations. The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 is amended to include provisions for electronic surveillance targets and locations, including cases where the target's presence at a specific facility is unknown at the time of the surveillance order. SEC. 3. LIMITATION ON AUTHORITY TO DELAY NOTICE OF SEARCH WARRANTS. Section 3103a of title 18, United States Code, is amended to specify conditions under which a search warrant may be executed, including endangering life or safety, flight from prosecution, or tampering with evidence. The time limit for executing the warrant is set at 7 days, extendable by the court for an additional 7 days each time. The amended Section 3103a of title 18, United States Code allows for a search warrant to be executed with a time limit of 7 days, extendable by the court for an additional 7 days under specific conditions such as endangering life or safety, flight from prosecution, or tampering with evidence. Additionally, the Attorney General is required to submit a report to Congress every 6 months summarizing requests for delays of notice and extensions related to warrants. The Department of Justice must report to Congress every 6 months on delays of notice and extensions related to search warrants under Section 3103a of title 18, United States Code. The report must include the number of requests for delays of notice, categorized as granted, denied, or pending, as well as the number of requests for extensions of the delay of notice. The Attorney General is required to make this report available to the public. The sunset provision in Section 3103a of title 18, United States Code, will expire on December 31, 2005, unless related to ongoing investigations or offenses that began before that date. Privacy protections for library, bookseller, and personal records under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978. The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 is amended to require specific and articulable facts to believe a person is a foreign power or agent for orders and applications. The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act of 1978 is amended to require specific facts to believe a person is a foreign power or agent for record production requests. The Attorney General must inform select committees semiannually about all requests for tangible things under the Act. Privacy protections for computer users at libraries under national security authority are outlined in Section 5. Section 2709 of title 18, United States Code is amended to include an exception for libraries, defining them as not being treated as a wire or electronic communication service provider. The term 'library' is defined to include services such as access to the Internet, books, journals, magazines, newspapers, or other forms of communication in print or digitally for patrons' use. SEC. 6. EXTENSION OF PATRIOT SUNSET PROVISION. Amends Section 224(a) of the USA PATRIOT ACT by removing certain sections and adding section 505.
